item.title: Michael Chiesa Tabs World-Class Athlete Who Would Find Success In MMA, Compares Him To LeBron James & Tom Brady
item.description: UFC fighter and analyst Michael Chiesa wants to see one non-MMA combat sports athlete make the transition to the cage. Chiesa has seen the highs and lows of MMA during his career in the UFC. After winning The Ultimate Fighter 15, the welterweight contender has gone on to have a successful UFC ...
item.dc:creator: Curtis Calhoun
item.content:encoded:
UFC fighter and analyst Michael Chiesa wants to see one non-MMA combat sports athlete make the transition to the cage.

Chiesa has seen the highs and lows of MMA during his career in the UFC. After winning The Ultimate Fighter 15, the welterweight contender has gone on to have a successful UFC career that includes wins over Carlos Condit, Rafael dos Anjos, and Beneil Dariush.

Chiesa has also become a top analyst for ESPN's UFC coverage. He's proven to be knowledgeable about the sport he loves and is a main fixture of the broadcast desk.

After Chiesa's former ESPN colleague, Dan Hardy, posed a question of who was one non-MMA athlete who could find success in the Octagon, Chiesa pointed to a top-level wrestler.

Michael Chiesa: Jordan Burroughs Would Shake Up MMA

In a recent tweet, Chiesa responded to Hardy's question with an intriguing answer.

My pick is Jordan Burroughs. He‚Äôs as dedicated to his craft as the Lebrons and Tom Bradys of the world. Then you factor in his toughness, tenacity, athleticism and IQ with his wrestling prowess. He could take the late start to MMA route that DC took and have a lot of success. https://t.co/sRGupsqlWO

— Michael Chiesa (@MikeMav22) June 9, 2023

"My pick is Jordan Burroughs," Chiesa tweeted. "He‚Äôs as dedicated to his craft as the Lebrons and Tom Bradys of the world. Then you factor in his toughness, tenacity, athleticism and IQ with his wrestling prowess. He could take the late start to MMA route that DC took and have a lot of success."

Some fans have clamored for Jordan Burroughs to make the move to MMA in recent years. He has dominated freestyle wrestling and earned an Olympic gold medal at the 2012 Summer Olympics in London.

Burroughs seriously considered a run in MMA before concerns about his long-term health, as he explained during an appearance on the Joe Rogan Experience. While he's cross-trained with several high-profile fighters in the UFC, it seems a move to the cage isn't in the cards.

Burroughs has captivated the wrestling world similarly to LeBron James and Tom Brady in their respective sports, and Chiesa feels he could make a similar impact on the UFC.

  • Read Also:  UFC 289 Sleeper Scrap: Mike Malott vs. Adam Fugitt

item.title: Former UFC Champion Targets End Of Summer Return After Not Fighting Since 2020
item.description: Former women‚Äôs featherweight champion Germaine de Randamie is planning a return to the UFC this year after last fighting in 2020. ‚ÄúThe Iron Lady‚Äù was one of the UFC‚Äôs top female talents at both bantamweight and featherweight prior to her current layoff, which came after she submitted Julianna Pe√±a ...
item.dc:creator: Drew Beaupr√©
item.content:encoded:
Former women‚Äôs featherweight champion Germaine de Randamie is planning a return to the UFC this year after last fighting in 2020.

‚ÄúThe Iron Lady‚Äù was one of the UFC‚Äôs top female talents at both bantamweight and featherweight prior to her current layoff, which came after she submitted Julianna Pe√±a on the main card of a UFC Fight Night in October 2020.

According to a recent clip posted by Eurosport Nederland, the 39-year-old intends to return to the Octagon by the end of the summer.

ü•äüá®üá¶ | #UFC289 | Germaine de Randamie is inmiddels terug in de gym en wil terugkeren aan het einde van de zomer in de Octagon.

De Nederlandse gaf haar voorspelling voor het titelgevecht tussen kampioene Amanda Nunes en Irene Aldana.

Bekijk het hele interview op Eurosport. pic.twitter.com/HPjzHsQqSM

— Eurosport Nederland (@Eurosport_NL) June 9, 2023

Germaine de Randemie Fought For UFC Titles In Two Weight Classes 

De Randamie‚Äôs decision to return at age 39 following a lengthy layoff is somewhat surprising news, but she does hold wins over some of the UFC‚Äôs top-ranked female fighters, Also, her only losses in the promotion came against two-division champion Amanda Nunes.

The Dutch fighter made her MMA debut in 2008 after a decorated career in kickboxing and Muay Thai. She joined the UFC in 2013 after the purchase of rival promotion Strikeforce.

De Randamie was stopped by Nunes in her second UFC bout, but after that finished two opponents to set up a fight for the UFC‚Äôs inaugural women‚Äôs featherweight belt against Holly Holm.

‚ÄúThe Iron Lady‚Äù bested Holm but was eventually stripped of the featherweight title when she failed to defend her belt, and another pair of victories at bantamweight earned her a second fight with Nunes at UFC 245, which she lost via unanimous decision.

De Randamie‚Äôs last win against Pe√±a has aged considerably well given that ‚ÄúThe Venezuelan Vixen‚Äù upset Nunes and briefly claimed the women‚Äôs bantamweight title last year. If she does intend to return at 135lbs, the 39-year-old will likely be watching this weekend‚Äôs UFC 289 main event between Nunes and Irene Aldana quite closely.

  • Read Also: Former UFC Champion Germaine de Reamdamie & Partner Sam Welcome Baby Boy

media:content.media:description: De Randamie's only UFC losses have come against Amanda Nunes. (Stephen R. Sylvanie/USA TODAY Sports)

item.title: Amanda Nunes' Former Opponent Makes Bold Claim About Irene Aldana Ahead Of UFC 289
item.description: One of Amanda Nunes' recent opponents thinks that Irene Aldana has what it takes to give the 135lb champion fits on the feet. Nunes returns to defend the bantamweight title in the UFC 289 headliner on Saturday. She reclaimed the bantamweight throne by earning a dominant win over Julianna Pe√±a at ...
item.dc:creator: Curtis Calhoun
item.content:encoded:
One of Amanda Nunes' recent opponents thinks that Irene Aldana has what it takes to give the 135lb champion fits on the feet.

Nunes returns to defend the bantamweight title in the UFC 289 headliner on Saturday. She reclaimed the bantamweight throne by earning a dominant win over Julianna Pe√±a at UFC 277 last July.

Nunes remains the pound-for-pound best female UFC fighter after her redemption, but she faces a tough test in the form of Aldana, a winner of four of her last five inside the Octagon.

Aldana has an elite boxing toolbox that could give Nunes some problems on the feet. It could be her best chance to pull off the massive upset this weekend.

Megan Anderson Thinks Irene Aldana Could Sleep Amanda Nunes

During a recent segment on SportsCenter, former UFC title challenger Megan Anderson claimed Aldana could devastatingly finish Nunes.

"The striking that Aldana brings to the table is what makes me so excited about this particular fight," Anderson said. "The willingness to sit down in the pocket and trade, she's not a sloppy striker to say the least. She's technical, crisp, and clean, she can throw any strike in any direction and that's what potentially could pose a threat to Amanda Nunes.

"We've seen Amanda Nunes have issues with Julianna Pe√±a in the striking department... Aldana's striking is levels above Pe√±a. For Pe√±a, it was about her inability to close the range," Anderson continued. "Aldana though, she's got the footwork, the timing, and if she can find that range early, she has potentially one of the biggest chances that we've seen in a while to put away the champ on the feet."

Nunes' lone knockout loss in the UFC came against Cat Zingano at UFC 178. She went on to win 12 consecutive fights before eventually falling to Pe√±a in their first matchup in December 2021.

The "Lioness," however, is no slouch on the feet, as she's demonstrated throughout her bantamweight title reigns. She has knocked out the likes of Ronda Rousey, Raquel Pennington, and Holly Holm during her run.

Aldana has the chance to hand Nunes one of her few setbacks in the UFC, and Anderson feels her striking could be the difference-maker this weekend.

  • Read Also: UFC 289: Amanda Nunes vs. Irene Aldana Weigh-In Live Stream & Results

Please provide transcription credit with a link to this article if you use any of these quotes.

item.title: UFC 289: Amanda Nunes vs. Irene Aldana Weigh-In Live Stream & Results
item.description: UFC 289 takes place tomorrow night, and MMA News is here to bring you the official weigh-in results! Saturday's numbered event marks the promotion's return to Canada for the first time since before the COVID-19 pandemic struck. The card, set for Vancouver's Rogers Arena, will be headlined by a ...
item.dc:creator: Harvey Leonard
item.content:encoded:
UFC 289 takes place tomorrow night, and MMA News is here to bring you the official weigh-in results!

Saturday's numbered event marks the promotion's return to Canada for the first time since before the COVID-19 pandemic struck. The card, set for Vancouver's Rogers Arena, will be headlined by a championship fight between reigning bantamweight titleholder Amanda Nunes and the #5-ranked Irene Aldana.

Much of the attention, however, has been on the co-main event, which will see former UFC lightweight champion Charles Oliveira share the Octagon with in-form contender Beneil Dariush. Both men are in pursuit of the next shot at ending Islam Makhachev's divisional rule.

With a potential barnburner between Dan Ige and Nate Landwehr also set for the main card, as well as a number of Canada's own littered throughout the lineup, UFC 289 looks to have the potential for an entertaining night of action from British Columbia despite not being seen by some as a PPV-quality event.

UFC 289: Amanda Nunes vs. Irene Aldana Weigh-In Results

UFC 289 takes place Saturday, June 10, at the Rogers Arena in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. The main card begins at 10 PM ET/7 PM PT, with the preliminary card starting at 7 PM ET/4 PM PT.

See above for a full replay of the UFC 289 Weigh-In Show, and check out the full results below!

Main Card:

  • Bantamweight Championship Main Event: Amanda Nunes (135lbs) vs. Irene Aldana (135lbs)
  • Lightweight Co-Main Event: Charles Oliveira (154lbs) vs. Beneil Dariush (156lbs)
  • Welterweight: Mike Malott (169.5lbs) vs. Adam Fugitt (170.75)
  • Featherweight: Dan Ige (145.5lbs) vs. Nate Landwehr (145.25lbs)
  • Middleweight: Marc-Andr√© Barriault (185lbs) vs. Eryk Anders (184.75lbs)

Preliminary Card:

  • Middleweight: Nassourdine Imavov (185.5lbs) vs. Chris Curtis (185.25lbs)
  • Flyweight: Miranda Maverick (125.5lbs) vs. Jasmine Jasudavicius (125.25lbs)
  • Bantamweight: Aiemann Zahabi (135.75lbs) vs. Aoriqileng (135lbs)
  • Featherweight: Kyle Nelson (145lbs) vs. Blake Bilder (145.5lbs)

Early Preliminary Card:

  • Flyweight: David Dvo≈ô√°k (125.5lbs) vs. Stephen Erceg (125.5lbs)
  • Strawweight: Diana Belbi≈£ƒÉ (114.5lbs) vs. Maria Oliveira (115.5lbs)

*Raquel Pennington successfully made weight (134.5lbs) as the main event backup fighter.

The women's bantamweight title main event is official üèÜ #UFC289 pic.twitter.com/4S4PIMwD4i

— ESPN MMA (@espnmma) June 9, 2023

item.title: Chris Curtis' Twitter Troll Becomes A Fan After Running Into 'Action Man' In Person: 'They Never Keep The Same Energy'
item.description: Plenty of fighters go out of their way to engage with fans, but UFC middleweight Chris Curtis recently had the unique opportunity to interact with one of his Twitter trolls in real life. ‚ÄúThe Action Man‚Äù is one of the UFC‚Äôs more active fighters in terms of his online presence, and as with any ...
item.dc:creator: Drew Beaupr√©
item.content:encoded:
Plenty of fighters go out of their way to engage with fans, but UFC middleweight Chris Curtis recently had the unique opportunity to interact with one of his Twitter trolls in real life.

‚ÄúThe Action Man‚Äù is one of the UFC‚Äôs more active fighters in terms of his online presence, and as with any public figure he‚Äôs had to deal with his fair share of criticism on social media. Curtis is usually happy to engage with or outright block such critics, but during UFC 289 fight week the 35-year-old had some fun by posting a clip of his interaction with someone that had apparently been harassing him online. Unsurprisingly, the online troll wasn't too forthcoming with his criticism face-to-face with Curtis.

Not every day, you get to run into one of your Twitter trolls. Lol, they never keep the same energy. But it's fine. I love you guys, too. Man I love üá®üá¶ pic.twitter.com/r5Ryk6y0yG

— Chris Curtis The Action Man (@Actionman513) June 9, 2023

Chris Curtis Looking To Rebound From Loss At UFC 289

Both Curtis and the ‚ÄúTwitter troll‚Äù certainly appeared to have some fun with the interaction, so perhaps ‚ÄúThe Action Man‚Äù is saving any frustration he may hold for when he takes on Nassourdine Imavov at this weekend‚Äôs UFC 289.

The two middleweights are set to compete in the night‚Äôs featured prelim, and both men are in need of a win to keep their place in the UFC rankings. Curtis currently sits at #14 after alternating wins and losses through his last few fights, while the #12 ranked Imavov had a three-fight win streak broken earlier this year when Curtis‚Äô friend and teammate Sean Strickland defeated him via unanimous decision.

That featured prelim promises to be arguably the most interesting fight of the UFC 289 undercard, but most fans will have their sights set on the action going down on the night‚Äôs main card. With all due respect to great matchups like Dan Ige vs. Nate Landwehr and the Sleeper Scrap between Mike Malott and Adam Fugitt, the card‚Äôs top two fights have demanded the majority of the attention leading up to the UFC‚Äôs return to Canada. 

The night's co-main event will see Charles Oliveira and Beneil Dariush square off in what many expect to be a number one contender fight for the lightweight division, and in the main event Amanda Nunes will defend her women‚Äôs bantamweight title against Irene Aldana.

Read Also: 'I Was Talking So Much S**t To Ciryl Gane' - Chris Curtis Details Wild Cornering Encounter With Sean Strickland

media:content.media:description: Curtis is coming off a unanimous decision loss to Kelvin Gastelum. (Rich Storry/USA TODAY Sports)

item.title: Johnny Walker's Undefeated 11-0 Brother Has Reportedly Been Signed By The UFC
item.description: The UFC has apparently added a significant name to its heavyweight division after signing the undefeated Valter Walker, who is the younger brother of top UFC light heavyweight Johnny Walker. It‚Äôs no secret that the lighter weight classes in MMA tend to have deeper pools of talent, so major ...
item.dc:creator: Drew Beaupr√©
item.content:encoded:
The UFC has apparently added a significant name to its heavyweight division after signing the undefeated Valter Walker, who is the younger brother of top UFC light heavyweight Johnny Walker.

It‚Äôs no secret that the lighter weight classes in MMA tend to have deeper pools of talent, so major promotions are always on the lookout for prospects that are capable of making an impact in the heavier divisions. According to a post from MMA Orbit, manager Gor Azizyan has confirmed that Valter Walker has inked a deal with the sport‚Äôs leading organization.

üö®| Valter Walker (11-0), brother of Johnny Walker, has been signed by the UFC, per his manager Gor Azizyan.#UFC #MMA pic.twitter.com/VqGCGaoJeO

— MMA Orbit (@mma_orbit) June 9, 2023

Valter Walker Brings Youth And Unbeaten Record To UFC's Heavyweight Division 

Having a talented brother already on the roster certainly doesn't hurt, but there‚Äôs a good chance that Valter‚Äôs impressive 11-0 record would have encouraged the UFC to come calling sooner rather than later.

‚ÄúThe Clean Monster‚Äù finished his first three opponents in the first round before joining noted Russian regional promotion MMA Series, where he proceeded to go 6-0 with a brief stop in Arena Global along the way. After claiming the MMA Series heavyweight title in May, the 25-year-old made a quick turnaround to fight at the co-promoted Titan FC 82/Serbian Battle Championship 47 card earlier this month.

Taking on UFC and PFL veteran Alex Nicholson, Valter slugged it out with ‚ÄúThe Spartan‚Äù before getting a stoppage victory in the fourth round. The Brazilian captured the Titan FC heavyweight title in the process, and the result marked his seventh finish out of eleven pro fights.

Valter will certainly have a tough act to follow when he joins the UFC, as Johnny is a fan-favorite that is currently in the best form of his career. The 31-year-old arrived in the promotion with a series of sensational finishes before suffering a run of tough results, but he‚Äôs now on a 3-fight win streak and is the UFC‚Äôs #5-ranked light heavyweight.

Read Also: Johnny Walker Responds To Bizarre Mid-Fight Claims Of Attacking Anthony Smith's Family

item.title: Video: Dan Hardy Can't Hide His Emotions On Commentary As Fellow Countryman Brendan Loughnane Gets KO'ed Stiff At PFL 4
item.dc:creator: Drew Beaupr√©
item.content:encoded:
Dan Hardy had a hard time remaining impartial as he watched his fellow Englishman Brendan Loughnane get knocked out in the headlining fight of PFL 4.

‚ÄúThe Outlaw‚Äù previously did some commentary work with the UFC after his fighting career ended, but he parted ways with the promotion in 2021 following an apparent disagreement with a UFC employee. Since then the 41-year-old has found success working as an analyst for the PFL along with other UFC veterans such as Randy Couture, Kenny Florian, and Sean O‚ÄôConnell.

The PFL returned from its midseason break on Thursday night with a PFL 4 card featuring light heavyweights and men‚Äôs featherweights fighting for a spot in the 2023 playoffs. 2022 featherweight champion Loughnane was given the card's main event slot against Jesus Pinedo.

Dan Hardy Watches Brendan Loughnane Get Finished At PFL 4

Loughnane was a significant favorite heading into the matchup with Pinedo but was caught by a well-timed knee within the first two minutes of the fight. Hardy was evidently at a loss for words during the brutal finishing sequence.

Dan Hardy‚Äôs reaction to fellow Englishman Brendan Loughnane being knocked out by Jesus Pinedo last night

pic.twitter.com/fxY9EICw47

— MMA Orbit (@mma_orbit) June 9, 2023

The loss was Loughnane‚Äôs first since he dropped a split decision to Movlid Khaybulaev in 2021. Beyond having a five-fight win streak broken, the result also means that the 33-year-old will miss out on PFL‚Äôs 2023 playoffs and won‚Äôt have the chance to defend the title he won last year.

Competing in his first PFL season, meanwhile, Pinedo came up short in his first fight against Gabriel Braga. However, he vaulted himself into the playoffs with a first-round finish of Loughnane that earned him six points in the featherweight standings. 

‚ÄúEl Mundo‚Äù will join his former opponent Braga, Khaybulaev, and last year's featherweight runner-up Bubba Jenkins as the four fighters with a chance at winning this season‚Äôs featherweight title and the $1 million prize that comes with it.

  • Read Also: Dan Hardy Compares Charles Oliveira Unfavorably With Amanda Nunes, Questions His 'Capacity' Ahead of UFC 289 Fight

item.title: Belal Muhammad Excited To 'Hit Somebody I Hate' In Fight Against Leon Edwards vs. Colby Covington Winner
item.description: UFC welterweight contender Belal Muhammad is sitting pretty in his division's title picture, with a shot at the gold expected for his next appearance inside the Octagon. Since a decision defeat to Geoff Neal back in 2019, "Remember the Name" has amassed an impressive 10-fight unbeaten streak. That ...
item.dc:creator: Harvey Leonard
item.content:encoded:
UFC welterweight contender Belal Muhammad is sitting pretty in his division's title picture, with a shot at the gold expected for his next appearance inside the Octagon.

Since a decision defeat to Geoff Neal back in 2019, "Remember the Name" has amassed an impressive 10-fight unbeaten streak. That run includes victories over Demian Maia, Stephen Thompson, and Vicente Luque.

But it's been Muhammad's most recent pair of outings that have seemingly helped cement himself a first opportunity at achieving championship status. After blemishing the record of Sean Brady last October, the 34-year-old Chicago-born fighter recorded his biggest win to date last month at UFC 288, where he outpointed Gilbert Burns.

While the contest with "Durinho" boasted high stakes, Muhammad has long shared a good relationship with the Brazilian. The same certainly can't be said for the man from whom he'll be standing across inside the Octagon next...

Muhammad 'Dislikes' Both Edwards & Covington

During a recent appearance on the 670 The Score sports show, Muhammad was asked whether he has an opponent preference.

With reigning UFC Welterweight Champion Leon Edwards expected to defend his title opposite Colby Covington next, Muhammad appears to be waiting in the wings for a collision with the victor down the line.

Having had public back-and-forth with both fighters in recent times, Muhammad expressed excitement at the possibility of striking someone he "hates" for a change.

"I actually dislike both of them," Muhammad said. "So, for me, the last couple of guys I fought, I was actually friends with. Gilbert Burns I was actually cool with. We've trained together before and he's a very nice guy. So, the next guy will be somebody I actually dislike, so it'll be a fun buildup and it'll be a fun fight for me, to actually hit somebody that I hate."

Muhammad's animosity with the champ dates back to their headliner in March 2021. The bout ended in a disappointing fashion, with an inadvertent poke from Edwards resulting in damage to Muhammad's eye and a no contest.

Having accused "Rocky" of rejecting a rematch, "Remember the Name" wouldn't mind running it back with the Jamaican-born Brit with the gold on the line.

But should "Chaos" dethrone Edwards, Muhammad has also long shared his desire to be locked in the cage with the polarizing former interim titleholder. As well as Muhammad dismissing Covington's credentials, the pair have exchanged racism allegations in recent months.

There‚Äôs only one real number one contender pic.twitter.com/KgxHzfYYyu

— Belal Muhammad (@bullyb170) May 24, 2023
  • Read Also: Belal Muhammad Follows Floyd Mayweather Approach To Striking: 'There's A Life After Fighting'

Please provide transcription credit with a link to this article if you use any of these quotes.

item.title: Charles Oliveira Challenges Beneil Dariush To Put His Money Where His Mouth Is With Grappling Confidence
item.description: While a piece of UFC gold will be on the line in this weekend's pay-per-view main event, the fight week numbers and attention on the co-headliner has left little doubt over which contest is the most anticipated. Setting the stage for Amanda Nunes' title defense against Irene Aldana at UFC 289 on ...
item.dc:creator: Harvey Leonard
item.content:encoded:
While a piece of UFC gold will be on the line in this weekend's pay-per-view main event, the fight week numbers and attention on the co-headliner has left little doubt over which contest is the most anticipated.

Setting the stage for Amanda Nunes' title defense against Irene Aldana at UFC 289 on Saturday night will be former lightweight kingpin Charles Oliveira and in-form contender Beneil Dariush.

The pair of elite 155lbers will enter the Octagon inside Vancouver's Rogers Arena in pursuit of the next opportunity at ending Islam Makhachev's reign. While "Do Bronx" is targeting redemption having suffered defeat to the Dagestani last October, his Iranian-born counterpart is confident that he won't let that happen.

In the buildup to the UFC's return to Canadian soil, Dariush has displayed a high level of self-belief, backing himself to overwhelm Oliveira in both the striking and grappling realms come fight night.

In fact, despite the Brazilian's prowess on the mat ‚Äî which has helped him tally up 16 submissions wins in the UFC, the most in both divisional and promotional history ‚Äî Dariush believes he'd defeat Oliveira in "nine out of 10" grappling matches.

Oliveira Tells Dariush: You Have Three Rounds To Test Your BJJ

During his appearance at UFC 289 media day on Wednesday, Oliveira responded to Dariush's confidence and firm grappling declaration.

While "Do Bronx" maintained that he has nothing but respect for his fellow lightweight contender, he challenged the Iranian-born American to put his money where his mouth is and test his jiu-jitsu this Saturday.

"You gotta be confident when you come into a fight like this," Oliveira said. "All the respect in the world for him. The one thing I've said many times: I'm an MMA fighter. I'm a complete fighter. I'm not a jiu-jitsu fighter. Well, if he feels so confident about his jiu-jitsu, he has three rounds to try to bring it down to the ground and see what's going on, and we'll see what happens."

Having begun his combat sports journey on the mats, becoming a decorated BJJ practitioner, Dariush would appear to have the credentials to hang with the UFC's most prolific submission specialist on the ground.

But although the #4-ranked contender has admitted that the prospect of tangling with "Do Bronx" is enticing, he's also acknowledged that a "dogfight" on the feet is on the cards.

Either way, entertainment appears guaranteed in the UFC 289 co-main event.

Lightweights EVERYWHERE will be watching üëÄ@CharlesDoBronxs vs @BeneilDariush in Saturday‚Äôs co-main!

item.title: UFC 289 Sleeper Scrap: Mike Malott vs. Adam Fugitt
item.description: Welcome to the MMA News‚Äô Sleeper Scrap! The relentless schedule of the MMA world means that some fans don‚Äôt have a full look at a fight card until days before the event, leaving the promoters to decide which bouts you should be paying the most attention to. Everyone wants to tune in for main events ...
item.dc:creator: Drew Beaupr√©
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the MMA News‚Äô Sleeper Scrap! The relentless schedule of the MMA world means that some fans don‚Äôt have a full look at a fight card until days before the event, leaving the promoters to decide which bouts you should be paying the most attention to.

Everyone wants to tune in for main events and fights that feature popular names, but that means meaningful or potentially action-packed matchups from elsewhere on fight cards sometimes get lost in the shuffle. A Sleeper Scrap might highlight interesting style matchups, fighters with notable storylines, or bouts that simply have the chance to be a Fight of the Night contender.

The Fighters

Mike Malott made his pro debut back in 2011, and after long periods of inactivity through his early career he‚Äôs now riding a five-fight streak of first-round finishes.

‚ÄúProper‚Äù ran through his first four opponents after turning pro and eventually joined the PFL, where he suffered his first career loss to current UFC featherweight Hakeem Dawodu.

Malott jumped over to Bellator the following year and fought to a majority draw with Thomas Diagne, and after securing another quick finish at XFFC 13, he had a nearly three-year layoff from competition.

The 31-year-old‚Äôs return at CFFC 91 saw him stop the previously undefeated Solomon Renfro, which led to a 39-second submission on Dana White's Contender Series 2021 that Malott has now followed with a pair of first-round finishes in the UFC.

Meanwhile, a brief three-fight amateur career saw Adam Fugitt finish all of his opponents via strikes, and he carried that streak into his 2016 pro debut when he finished Amin Kajtaz in the second round.

Fugitt collected another win before dropping a decision to future UFC lightweight Austin Vanderford, and he then finished back-to-back opponents before being knocked out in the first round of his LFA debut. Three more finishes brought him back to the LFA in 2022, and after he scored his own victory over Renfro, he stepped up on short-notice to fight at UFC 277.

The 34-year-old gave the undefeated Michael Morales all he could handle before being knocked out in the third round, but Fugitt earned his first UFC victory when he stopped Yusaku Kinoshita with ground and pound earlier this year.

The Matchup

Although he‚Äôs most comfortable from orthodox stance, both of Malott‚Äôs fights in the UFC have seen the Canadian have success by starting his fights from southpaw. 

‚ÄúProper‚Äù does a good job of doubling up on his jab to set up big power shots, with his overhand right and left hook being particularly dangerous. Malott also like to end his combinations with a leg kick or mix in some high kicks, and when pressured by opponents, he‚Äôs usually adapt at circling out of danger.

Fight fans saw the 31-year-old flash his power in his UFC debut against Mickey Gall, but Malott is arguably even more dangerous as a submission threat and is capable of finishing the fight after landing a takedown or as his opponents try to bring things to the mat.

Fugitt will hold a four-inch reach advantage over Malott, and although he‚Äôs not the cleanest striker he packs plenty of power and is more than capable of ending things on the feet. 

A southpaw, Fugitt relies a lot on his rear leg and will repeatedly throw high kicks if his opponents don‚Äôt make an effort to counter the attack. He also will time kicks to the open side of orthodox opponents, as well as repeatedly poke at their midsections with front kicks. The awkward angle that he throws some of his punches at can easily catch fighters off guard.

The 34-year-old makes good use of clinches and takedowns to halt pressure from his opponents, and he also excels at transitioning between takedown attempts in order to get things to the ground and land big strikes on the mat.

The Stakes

The inclusion of this fight on the UFC 289 main card is somewhat surprising considering each man is still early in their tenure with the UFC, but Malott's last two wins may have the promotion hoping he can score another impressive finish in front of the Canadian crowd.

The fact that all of Malott‚Äôs nine wins have come in the first round is an incredible statistic, and naturally it creates some question marks around how he might perform if Fugitt takes things beyond the opening five minutes. 

The 34-year-old already showed off some incredible durability in his UFC debut against Morales, and he seems like exactly the type of fighter that could make things difficult for Malott if the Canadian is expecting a quick night of work.

Even though neither man has a particularly extensive pro record, both welterweights are in their 30‚Äôs and likely know that a loss could put them just a fight or two away from exiting the UFC. There may be more pressure on Fugitt given that he‚Äôs 1-1 in the promotion, but a loss for Malott would also derail the momentum he‚Äôs established after starting his own UFC run in such impressive fashion.

Malott is a massive threat to end things in the first round but Fugitt is also a dangerous finisher in his own right, and this bout certainly has all the potential to be one of the highlights of the night at UFC 289.

You can catch up on previous editions of the MMA News' Sleeper Scrap right here!

item.title: Marlon Moraes Retires After Seventh Consecutive Stoppage Loss At PFL 4
item.description: Professional Fighters League (PFL) featherweight Marlon Moraes has officially retired after suffering a loss to Gabriel Braga at PFL 4 on June 8. The fight ended inside the first round, as Braga landed a straight right followed by several punches on the ground to get the TKO victory. Braga's win ...
item.dc:creator: Tyriece Simon
item.content:encoded:
Professional Fighters League (PFL) featherweight Marlon Moraes has officially retired after suffering a loss to Gabriel Braga at PFL 4 on June 8.

The fight ended inside the first round, as Braga landed a straight right followed by several punches on the ground to get the TKO victory. Braga's win moved his points tally to nine for the 2023 regular season, leaving him in second place in the PFL featherweight standings.

Unfortunately for Moraes, the result marked his seventh straight defeat, with every setback in that run coming by way of a finish. And after his latest difficult loss, the former WSOF champion and UFC bantamweight title challenger decided to remove his gloves and retire from MMA.

"Magic" had previously retired upon his exit from the UFC before deciding to continue his career in PFL. The decision to sign with the organization, formerly known as World Series of Fighting, was in the hope that he could have the same success as earlier in his career. Fans may remember Moraes had a great stint in WSOF as the bantamweight champion, successfully defending the title five times. 

From Challenger Series to the 2023 #PFLPlayoffs!

We will see you in San Antonio Gabriel Braga!#PFLRegularSeason LIVE NOW
üá∫üá∏ ESPN+
üåé https://t.co/jPNvomD5xg pic.twitter.com/piD8M6pUkV

— PFL (@PFLMMA) June 9, 2023

However, after suffering a knockout loss to Sheymon Moraes in his comeback fight last November, Moraes' woes continued when he fought 2022 PFL Featherweight Champion Brendan Loughnane at the season-opening PFL 1 event on April 1, losing via TKO in the second round. 

Moraes downplayed his losing streak ahead of his fight with Braga and promised a win at PFL 4. Ultimately, the victory for Braga was the final straw for Moraes to end his MMA career for good. 

Despite the disappointing defeat, Moraes expressed in a post-fight interview that he was happy to end his career with the PFL.

Marlon Moraes Speaks On Retiring After His Loss To Gabriel Braga 

As he dealt with the emotions of losing to Braga, Moraes was given the time to say farewell to the PFL fans and share his gratitude for ending his career on his terms. 

"I start here with World Series of Fighting, and when I announced my retirement, I was in UFC. I wasn't home. Now I'm home," Moraes said. "I wish I had better performances here, but guys, I give all my heart. I train hard. I can look at myself in the mirror every day and be proud of myself, and I've been kickboxing, MMA since I was nine. I'm 35. That's 26 years that I gave all my life to this.

"I thank Anderson, my coach. I thank Ali Abdelaziz, my manager, I thank Ray Sefo for the opportunity, and I thank all the fans right here, and I wish PFL is going to be number one in the world and this guy that I just fought, I wish him the best," Moraes continued. "I wish everyone the best. He's a great fighter and man, I gave my heart to the sport, and thank you, god. God gave me all I have. I can't be sad today. I'm happy. Man, I have a beautiful wife and two kids. I'm a happy man."

Moraes ended his MMA career with a record of 23-13-1 and was a former WSOF bantamweight champion. He's had notable victories over Aljamain Sterling, Jos√© Aldo, and Raphael Assun√ß√£o. While it may not have ended entirely how he may have wanted, Moraes had a great career.

MMA Fighting was the first publication to report news of the Ara√∫jo vs. O'Neill booking on Thursday. O'Neill returns to avenge her first career loss to Jennifer Maia at UFC 286 in ...
item.dc:creator: Curtis Calhoun
item.content:encoded:
UFC flyweights Casey O'Neill and Viviane Ara√∫jo are set to clash at the upcoming UFC 293 pay-per-view on September 9.

MMA Fighting was the first publication to report news of the Ara√∫jo vs. O'Neill booking on Thursday.

O'Neill returns to avenge her first career loss to Jennifer Maia at UFC 286 in March. Before that, she won her first four UFC fights, including finishes of Lara Fritzen and Antonina Shevchenko.

After a split decision win against Roxanne Modafferi at UFC 271, O'Neill suffered injuries that resulted in a one-year layoff. Her fight with Maia was her first fight back, ending in a unanimous decision defeat.

Casey O'Neill vs. Viviane Ara√∫jo Added To UFC 293

Casey O'Neill vs. Viviane Araujo set for #UFC293 in Australia on Sept. 9, per multiple sources confirmed to myself and @guicruzzz

The matchup was initially reported by @MayerMeni but the date is actually at UFC 293.

Full story coming to @MMAFighting

— Damon Martin (@DamonMartin) June 9, 2023

O'Neill's next fight will mark a home outing of sorts, with the Scottish-born fighter moving Down Under aged 10. Her combat sports journey began in Australia, where she started training in Brazilian jiu-jitsu at the age of 13.

"King Casey" faces a tough test next in the form of Ara√∫jo. Despite back-to-back losses to Amanda Ribas and Alexa Grasso, she remains a dangerous contender in the women's flyweight division.

Ara√∫jo recorded last win against Andrea Lee almost exactly one year ago. She has also defeated the likes of Modafferi, Montana De La Rosa, and Alexis Davis during her UFC tenure.

The September 10 card doesn't have a main event bout as of this writing, but with it making the first of three planned Sydney-held PPVs in the coming years, Oceania's Israel Adesanya is expected to headline.

Victoria passed away due to an undisclosed cause in December, a death that shocked the MMA community. The 18-year-old was considered one of the top female MMA prospects and was ...
item.dc:creator: Curtis Calhoun
item.content:encoded:
ONE atomweight champion Angela Lee is allegedly done fighting after the tragic death of her sister, Victoria, in December.

Victoria passed away due to an undisclosed cause in December, a death that shocked the MMA community. The 18-year-old was considered one of the top female MMA prospects and was 3-0 in her career at the time of her passing.

The Lee family continues to grieve her death and will likely continue to do so for years to come. Two of Victoria's siblings, Christian and Angela, haven't fought since the tragedy.

Chatri Sityodtong Updates On Angela, Christian Lee Returns

During a recent Facebook Watch video, ONE CEO Chatri Sityodtong gave a grim update on Angela's return to fighting.

‚ÄúAngela Lee is likely not coming back due to the loss of her sister,‚Äù Sityodtong said. ‚ÄúChristian Lee told me that he wants to come back. Stamp [Fairtex] and Seo Hee Ham will fight in August for the ONE Atomweight championship.‚Äù

Angela last fought for the ONE strawweight title last October, losing via unanimous decision. She earned the inaugural ONE atomweight belt in May 2016.

Christian, the ONE lightweight and welterweight champion, defeated Kiamrian Abbasov in November. He is 17-4 in his professional MMA career.

If Angela is done with her fighting career, she retires with an 11-3 record. She is 26 years old.

ONE continues to remember the loss of Victoria at numerous events, including in a pre-event ceremony earlier this year.

All quotes from Beyond Fighting

item.title: Deontay Wilder Shows Up At PFL 4, Teases Two-Fight Francis Ngannou Showdown
item.description: Boxing superstar Deontay Wilder surprised MMA fans by appearing at PFL 4 on June 8 during their live broadcast. Wilder is in talks to have his long-awaited heavyweight showdown with Anthony Joshua in December. talkSPORT's Simon Jordan reported earlier this year that Saudi Arabia has an interest in ...
item.dc:creator: Tyriece Simon
item.content:encoded:
Boxing superstar Deontay Wilder surprised MMA fans by appearing at PFL 4 on June 8 during their live broadcast.

Wilder is in talks to have his long-awaited heavyweight showdown with Anthony Joshua in December. talkSPORT's Simon Jordan reported earlier this year that Saudi Arabia has an interest in having Wilder take on Joshua, and Oleksandr Usyk and Tyson Fury colliding in a title unification bout. Wilder's trainer Malik Scott and Joshua's promoter Eddie Hearn have acknowledged that a fight between the two heavyweights is being discussed. 

Hearn gave an update in a recent interview with iF, stating that he's received an offer from Saudia Arabia without a contract. The anticipated heavyweight clash with Wilder and Joshua seems to be heading in the right direction, but it hasn't stopped "The Bronze Bomber" from looking at future opportunities. 

Deontay Wilder Teases MMA Transition, Targets PFL's Ngannou 

When he appeared at PFL 4, Wilder spoke with Randy Couture, Sean O'Connell, and Kenny Florian to update them on his fighting career, sharing that he could be boxing in August or September.

O'Connell later asked "The Bronze Bomber" about fighting in MMA, and Wilder expressed interest. 

"I thought about this many times," Wilder said. "Even with Ngannou, we were talking about getting together. You always see the MMA guys crossing over, but you never see the boxers crossing over, so I said I'm willing to make it more interesting for the fans and just the whole combat family as in a whole. I said why don't you come to my backyard, and after we handle business, I can come to yours and crossover and I really meant it. So things are still up in the air, but I have seen myself on this side of the field, you know. People will be very impressed on what I can do in my abilities to be here."

Just spoke to Deontay Wilder here at PFL in Atlanta. He really liked the 4oz gloves üëÄüëÄ

Stay tuned to @MirrorFighting for all from our chat! pic.twitter.com/Ottxtd5S6R

— Donagh Corby (@DonaghCorby_) June 9, 2023

Wilder also tried on the PFL gloves backstage, which he seemed to like. The promotion later had "The Bronze Bomber" back on the broadcast to speak with Couture and O'Connell, and the boxing superstar continued to tease a crossover fight with Ngannou. 

"Aye Francis, if you listening, we discussed this before, and hey, we got many space and opportunity to discuss it once more," Wilder stated. " Aye, I'm looking for a two-fight crossing over. I'm willing to just go in the octagon as well as the original plans, but you know,  the fans want to see it. I want to be a part of it. So let's give them what they want to see."

Wilder could be in a PFL cage if given the right offer. However, if Saudia Arabia is serious about having Wilder vs. Joshua, don't expect to see "The Bronze Bomber" risk potentially the biggest payday of his career to fight Ngannou this year. 

  • Read Also: Tom Aspinall: If There's A Top Boxer Francis Ngannou Could Beat, It's Deontay Wilder

item.title: 2023 PFL 4 Results & Highlights: Jesus Pinedo Upsets Brendan Loughnane
item.description: The Professional Fighters League‚Äôs midseason break finally came to an end when the promotion kicked off the second half of the 2023 regular season with a card featuring light heavyweights and men‚Äôs featherweights. The event took place at the Overtime Elite Arena in Atlanta, Georgia, with fighters ...
item.dc:creator: Drew Beaupr√©
item.content:encoded:
The Professional Fighters League‚Äôs midseason break finally came to an end when the promotion kicked off the second half of the 2023 regular season with a card featuring light heavyweights and men‚Äôs featherweights.

The event took place at the Overtime Elite Arena in Atlanta, Georgia, with fighters looking to secure their spots in the 2023 PFL playoffs and earn a chance at the $1 million prize awarded to the champion of each weight class.

The 2023 million dollar journey heats up in the ATL as playoff spots are on the lineüî•

Here‚Äôs what you need to know!

[ Thursday, June 8th | 10pm ET on ESPN | #PFLRegularSeason | üéüÔ∏è https://t.co/Skcq84VUo6] pic.twitter.com/8vN0vkzFlF

— PFL (@PFLMMA) June 6, 2023

The card was headlined by 2022 PFL Featherweight Champion Brendan Loughnane taking on Jesus Pinedo, which ended in shocking fashion when "El Mundo" finished the former champion in less than two minutes. 

Loughnane was bumped from a playoff spot with the loss, but both Movlid Khaybulaev and Bubba Jenkins secured their chance at the PFL's featherweight title with submission wins. 

The light heavyweight action saw Josh Silveira take the top spot in the standings after Delan Monte injured his knee, and he'll be joined by Impa Kasanganay, Marthin Hamlet, and Ty Flores in this season's playoffs. 

The final prelim fight of the night also saw Gabriel Braga secure a playoff spot in his first PFL season, while his opponent Marlon Moraes decided to call it a career after suffering yet another knockout loss.

You can check out the full results and highlights from 2023 PFL 4 below!

2023 PFL 4 Results 

Main Card 

  • Featherweight Main Event: Jesus Pinedo def. Brendan Loughnane via KO: R1, 1:34
  • Featherweight Co-Main Event: Movlid Khaybulaev def. Tyler Diamond via Submission (Arm-Triangle Choke): R2, 4:23
  • Light Heavyweight Bout: Marthin Hamlet def. Sam Kei via Unanimous Decision (29-28x3)
  • Featherweight Bout: Bubba Jenkins def. Sung Bin Jo via Submission (Rear-Naked Choke): R1, 1:25
  • Light Heavyweight Bout: Josh Silveira def. Delan Monte via TKO (Leg Injury): R1, 1:30

    Preliminary Card 

    • Featherweight Bout: Gabriel Alves Braga def. Marlon Moraes via KO: R1, 3:02
    • Light Heavyweight Bout: Ty Flores def. Dan Spohn via Unanimous Decision (30-27, 29-28x2)
    • Featherweight Bout: Chris Wade def. Ryoji Kudo via Submission (Guillotine Choke): R1, 4:15
    • Light Heavyweight Bout: Impa Kasanganay def. Tim Caron via Submission (Arm-Triangle Choke): R2, 3:52
    • Light Heavyweight Bout: Andrew Sanchez def. Taylor Johnson via Split Decision (29-27x2, 27-29)
    • Women's Featherweight Bout: Abigail Montes def. Brandy Hester via TKO: R1, 3:06
    • Featherweight Bout: Alexei Pergande def. Akeem Bashir via Submission (D'Arce Choke): R1, 3:14

    Highlights

UFC Bantamweight Champion Amanda Nunes headlines against the surging Irene Aldana. The co-main event is a main-event-esque matchup ...
item.dc:creator: Curtis Calhoun
item.content:encoded:
UFC 289 fight week is in full swing after the pre-fight press conference at the Rogers Arena on Thursday.

UFC 289 marks the long-awaited return of the UFC to Canada. UFC Bantamweight Champion Amanda Nunes headlines against the surging Irene Aldana.

The co-main event is a main-event-esque matchup between Charles Oliveira and Beneil Dariush. The winner could potentially earn themselves the next lightweight title shot.

The UFC 289 main card fighters promoted the fights at the pre-fight press conference. Up-and-coming contenders like Nate Landwehr and Mike Malott will showcase their skillsets on the world stage.

Check out some of the highlights and faceoffs from the UFC 289 pre-fight press conference below.

item.title: Undefeated 20-Year-Old Evelyn Martins Is Loving The Challenge Of First 'Hectic' PFL Season (Exclusive)
item.description: 20-year-old PFL featherweight Evelyn Martins is soaking in the struggles of competing in one of MMA's toughest tests. The PFL's lone female-led division is without arguably the league's biggest star in Kayla Harrison. During her absence, many featherweights have made a name for themselves in ...
item.dc:creator: Curtis Calhoun
item.content:encoded:
20-year-old PFL featherweight Evelyn Martins is soaking in the struggles of competing in one of MMA's toughest tests.

The PFL's lone female-led division is without arguably the league's biggest star in Kayla Harrison. During her absence, many featherweights have made a name for themselves in stunning fashion, including Martins with her impressive win at PFL 2 over the previously unbeaten Karolina Sobek.

Just a couple of years removed from high school, Martins earned a shot with back-to-back wins earlier this year on the PFL's Challenger Series. Her upcoming fight with Marina Moknatkina on June 16th will be her fourth fight in six months, a jaw-dropping pace.

Evelyn Martins Endorses Former PFL Champ For Early Career Success

During an exclusive interview with MMANews, Martins opened up on how she's handled the chaos of the 2023 PFL season at such as young age.

"Everything that happens right now, I love everything about fighting, train every day whether I have a fight or not," Martins said. "I'm just loving the whole process...I'm tough, I'm a tough 20-year-old girl. Not easy to beat. I've been fighting since I was 11 and everything I've gone through this year with all the fights, I love that and I love the craziness.

"I can do this as many times they ask me too...I can do it all."

Martins then pointed to a former PFL champion teammate, Raush Manfio, as a massive reason for her success this season.

"I have a great connection with Raush," Martins said. "2021 champion, his history is crazy and everything he went through is similar to what I've gone through. We've fought in other promotions before getting to the PFL...gives me a better format for training and always gives me great tips...busier training so I don't feel weak, he's taught me a lot already."

  • Read Also: Henry Cejudo Outlines One Area Where Charles Oliveira Is The Best In UFC History

item.title: Daniel Cormier Dismisses Jim Miller's Case For Future UFC Hall Of Fame Induction
item.description: Daniel Cormier feels Jim Miller is a great fighter, but not one with merit for the prestigious UFC Hall of Fame. Miller earned the 36th win of his professional MMA career last weekend over short-notice replacement Jesse Butler. He was originally supposed to face Jared Gordon before Gordon's ...
item.dc:creator: Curtis Calhoun
item.content:encoded:
Daniel Cormier feels Jim Miller is a great fighter, but not one with merit for the prestigious UFC Hall of Fame.

Miller earned the 36th win of his professional MMA career last weekend over short-notice replacement Jesse Butler. He was originally supposed to face Jared Gordon before Gordon's withdrawal and ended up knocking out Butler in 23 seconds.

It was an impressive win for Miller, who has now won four of his last five fights and holds the records for most wins and bouts in UFC history.

Miller is aiming to make UFC 300 next year his last UFC fight, although it's uncertain if he's still planning to retire amidst his recent success. He made his UFC debut at UFC 89, submitting David Baron.

Miller's UFC records make a case for potential UFC Hall of Fame induction, despite his lack of titles and big-name wins to support it. But, Cormier doesn't think Miller's accomplishments mean he should be inducted.

Daniel Cormier: Jim Miller Isn't A UFC Hall of Famer

During a recent segment of DC&RC, Cormier explained why he feels Miller isn't UFC Hall of Fame worthy.

"I don‚Äôt feel like time served immediately puts you in the Hall of Fame," Cormier said of Miller. "Look, he‚Äôs got more wins than anyone else. But I love Jim Miller and that makes it hard for me ‚Äì but I just don‚Äôt feel like time served puts you in the Hall of Fame...

"There‚Äôs an offensive lineman in the NFL right now that played 20 years. Is that guy going into the Hall of Fame just because he played 20 years? It doesn‚Äôt work that way, RC. You have to have accomplishments to go into the Hall of Fame.‚Äù

Cormier was inducted into the UFC Hall of Fame last year alongside his longtime teammate Khabib Nurmagomedov. He retired following a trilogy loss to Stipe Miocic at UFC 252.

Cormier's comments come as Donald Cerrone is set to enter the UFC Hall of Fame this summer. Cerrone lost to Miller in his last fight at UFC 276 and will enter the UFC HOF despite never earning a belt in the promotion.

Time will tell if Miller will enter the UFC Hall of Fame, although Cormier thinks an induction for the veteran could create a poor precedent for the prestigious honor going forward.

  • Read Also: Irene Aldana Reveals How Teammate, New Champion Alexa Grasso Motivated Her Ahead Of Amanda Nunes Clash At UFC 289

H/T MMA Mania for the transcribed quotes

item.title: Jorge Masvidal Has A Surprising Prediction For Potential Israel Adesanya vs. Bo Nickal Fight
item.description: Since getting into MMA, UFC middleweight Bo Nickal has gained the attention of the fans and his peers. After winning two fights on Dana White's Contender Series in 2022, he joined the company. In his UFC debut, he submitted Jamie Pickett in the first round at UFC 285 on March 4. The win was ...
item.dc:creator: Tyriece Simon
item.content:encoded:
Since getting into MMA, UFC middleweight Bo Nickal has gained the attention of the fans and his peers.

After winning two fights on Dana White's Contender Series in 2022, he joined the company. In his UFC debut, he submitted Jamie Pickett in the first round at UFC 285 on March 4. The win was controversial, as Nickal appeared to accidentally land a low blow that referee Keith Peterson didn't see and that ultimately contributed to the takedown.

Nickal will hope to eliminate the memory of that controversy in his next fight against Tresean Gore at UFC 290 on July 8. He is currently a huge favorite, according to DraftKings, at -850. However, some are already looking past his opponent and believe he could be a title contender soon.

In an interview with Chamatkar Sandhu on May 18, former two-division UFC kingpin Henry Cejudo shared that he believes Nickal could become a champion in the promotion despite only competing four times in professional MMA to date. 

While not going as far as Cejudo, former welterweight star Jorge Masvidal also thinks Nickal has what it takes to reach the top. 

Jorge Masvidal Praises Bo Nickal's Grappling

Masvidal recently appeared on BS with Jake Paul and spoke highly of Nickal, explaining what it was like seeing the elite grappler train at American Top Team prior to his MMA transition. The former BMF champ noted that he has followed Nickal since he competed in wrestling for Penn State University. 

"Gamebred" also hosted Nickal's debut MMA fight under his own promotional banner, Jorge Masvidal's iKon FC 3, last June. Nickal defeated John Noland by knockout in just 33 seconds. 

"I get to meet him at American Top Team, then we get to start training, and I was like, 'Man, this guy is just as good as I thought or better,'" Masvidal said of Nickal. "I can tell when someone is a good wrestler. I might not be the best wrestler, but I know like, what a good wrestler looks like. So I was like, 'This guy got legit talent to maybe take it overseas and compete for world championships and stuff,' and so when he did the hard left and went into fighting, I was like, this is going to be interesting, bro, to see what comes out of it, and he's killing it."

On Nickal's wrestling ability, Masvidal explained that "The Allen Assassin" could dominate any opponent if he gets his hands on them. 

"I'm telling you right now, because I've seen him in the room, If he locks his hands on a lot of dudes, it's like, game over for that round," Masvidal stated. "He might just take a dude down and like, this guy is a nightmare, bro, to f*cking have on top of you."

Jorge Masvidal Predicts Bo Nickal vs. Israel Adesanya

Paul, a YouTuber-turned-boxer who has also trained with Nickal in recent months, later asked the former BMF champion if the relative newcomer could defeat current UFC Middleweight Champion Israel Adesanya.

Masvidal acknowledged that "The Last Stylebender" is talented, but he implied that Nickal could change the course of the potential fight in his favor with his grappling abilities. 

"I think it's young in his career right now, way young in his career right now," Masvidal explained. "But like I said, just right now, if he locks on a limb, good luck on Izzy getting away from him, though, and I've seen Izzy through his whole UFC career. Great athlete and good wrestling, but guys like Bo are just like, different.

"You can put him in the worst position, like, completely sprawled up, but his hands are like, locked, these guys find a way to just build back up, put you against the fence, and take you down and do it consecutively," Masvidal continued. "Once they lock, it's a different type of level, man. I don't think Izzy, no, I don't think, I know he's never competed against a wrestler that decorated, you know?"

Nickal's career is interesting as he has the support from his peers and fans who believe he can become a UFC champion. However, he must deal with the pressure of meeting people's expectations.

While Masvidal and Cejudo believe he could be a champion, we'll have to see how he does against Gore before fans can speculate about a fight against the likes of Adesanya.

  • Read Also: Bo Nickal's Confidence Branded "Disrespectful To Pioneers Of The Sport" By Next Opponent

item.title: Henry Cejudo Outlines One Area Where Charles Oliveira Is The Best In UFC History
item.description: Henry Cejudo believes that Charles Oliveira is the greatest submission specialist to ever step into the UFC‚Äôs Octagon. Oliveira is set to take on Beneil Dariush in the co-main event of UFC 289, and the lightweight matchup is the card‚Äôs most highly anticipated fight in the eyes of many fans. ...
item.dc:creator: Drew Beaupr√©
item.content:encoded:
Henry Cejudo believes that Charles Oliveira is the greatest submission specialist to ever step into the UFC‚Äôs Octagon.

Oliveira is set to take on Beneil Dariush in the co-main event of UFC 289, and the lightweight matchup is the card‚Äôs most highly anticipated fight in the eyes of many fans.

The pair were originally scheduled to meet at UFC 288 before ‚Äúdo Bronx‚Äù was forced to withdraw with an injury. The delay has seemingly only created more hype around the matchup.

Former two-division champion Cejudo has continued breaking down high-profile UFC bouts even now that he‚Äôs returned to fighting, and in his latest, ‚ÄúTriple C‚Äù insisted that Oliveira‚Äôs submission skills are unrivaled.

‚ÄúHe is super witty with his submissions,‚Äù Cejudo said on his YouTube channel. ‚ÄúThe best submission specialist that the UFC has ever offered. Even above Demian Maia. This guy is able to transition into a variety of different submissions and he‚Äôs good at everything. If there‚Äôs one area that I could say he‚Äôs 100% at ‚Äì typically I don‚Äôt do this, because nobody‚Äôs one hundred ‚Äì his submission game.‚Äù

Henry Cejudo Praises "Extremely Dangerous" Charles Oliveira 

Placing Oliveira‚Äôs submission skills above a legend like Maia is certainly lofty praise, and Cejudo believes the reason ‚Äúdo Bronx‚Äù is so dangerous is because he‚Äôs able to finish fights from any position.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a threat everywhere. He‚Äôs a threat on the neck, on the heels, on the knees, on the arms. He‚Äôs got submissions coming from everywhere. It‚Äôs almost like when you train for a guy to fight like Charles ‚Äòdo Bronx‚Äô, you‚Äôre gonna have to be holding five aces because the dude is extremely dangerous.‚Äù

As effective a finisher as Oliveira may be, there‚Äôs an argument to be made that Dariush is one of the only UFC lightweights capable of hanging with the Brazilian both on the feet and on the mat.

Currently sitting at #4 in the UFC‚Äôs lightweight rankings, the Iranian-born American is riding an eight-fight win streak and will be hoping that a win over Oliveira at UFC 289 will finally earn him a lightweight title shot.

The UFC 289 co-main event between Oliveira and Dariush should no doubt thrill fans as part of the UFC‚Äôs return to Canada after four years away. After the two lightweights throw down, the night‚Äôs headlining fight will see Amanda Nunes defend her women‚Äôs bantamweight title against Irene Aldana.

  • Read Also: Charles Oliveira Reacts To Talk Of BMF Champion Leapfrogging him For LW Title Shot

item.title: Robert Whittaker Hints That Kai Kara-France Replicating Israel Adesanya's Style Could Have Lost Him Amir Albazi Fight
item.description: Robert Whittaker has suggested that a striking approach reminiscent of Israel Adesanya may have contributed to Kai Kara-France‚Äôs recent loss to Amir Albazi. Kara-France and Albazi met in the main event of last weekend‚Äôs UFC Fight Night event, and many fans were looking at the fight as a potential ...
item.dc:creator: Drew Beaupr√©
item.content:encoded:
Robert Whittaker has suggested that a striking approach reminiscent of Israel Adesanya may have contributed to Kai Kara-France‚Äôs recent loss to Amir Albazi.

Kara-France and Albazi met in the main event of last weekend‚Äôs UFC Fight Night event, and many fans were looking at the fight as a potential title eliminator for the flyweight division.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Blink‚Äù entered the bout after losing an interim title fight to current UFC Flyweight Champion Brandon Moreno at UFC 277, but he ended up dropping back-to-back fights for the first time in his promotional career when he lost a split decision.

The scoring of the fight faced immediate scrutiny after the decision was read, and a recent episode of the MMArcade Podcast included a suggestion from Whittaker that neither man had appeared particularly willing to push for a victory.

‚ÄúIt was for the number one contender spot, Kai getting another shot at that and Amir running for the belt,‚Äù Whittaker said. ‚ÄúSo I feel like they should have been trying to push that pace a little bit. And you‚Äôve gotta give it to Amir, he was pushing forward. Which I think is what led the judges to believe he was winning that fight, that swayed the judges in that direction.‚Äù

Whittaker Compares Kara-France's Approach To Adesanya's

Kara-France soundly out-landed Albazi in terms of significant strikes, but Whittaker went on to say that his fellow Oceanic native was focusing too much on landing counter punches for large portions of the fight.

‚ÄúA big vibe I was getting across from Kai was just that he was really waiting for that counter, he was waiting for that moment where he can just step back, bang bang. Almost like his teammate Izzy Adesanya. He was kind of fighting like that, like very defensive counter striking. I think it works so well for Adesanya because of his body type and his body structure, I think he‚Äôs built for that style of fighting. But with Kai I feel like one of Kai‚Äôs strongest points is that he looks so dangerous moving forward. And you can see in the fight how fast Amir backed out of the positions when Kai was putting the foot down.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe Reaper‚Äù is certainly familiar with Adesanya‚Äôs style after sharing the cage with him on two occasions. They first met at UFC 243, where ‚ÄúThe Last Stylebender‚Äù claimed Whittaker‚Äôs middleweight title with a second-round knockout. The two had a competitive rematch at UFC 271 before Adesanya briefly lost his title to Alex Pereira, but the 32-year-old avenged that loss earlier this year.

Whittaker has already rebounded from his second loss to Adesanya by winning a decision over Marvin Vettori, and many fans expect the winner of his upcoming UFC 290 bout with Dricus Du Plessis to be the next challenger at 185 pounds.

item.title: Jorge Masvidal Faces GSP Scenario, Requires UFC's Permission To Feature In Boxing Fights After MMA Retirement
item.description: Earlier this year, former UFC welterweight Jorge Masvidal decided to hang up the mixed martial arts gloves after nearly 20 years in the sport. In 2019, Masvidal had his best year in MMA, rising to stardom and winning the BMF title against Nate Diaz at UFC 244. However, that was the last win of ...
item.dc:creator: Tyriece Simon
item.content:encoded:
Earlier this year, former UFC welterweight Jorge Masvidal decided to hang up the mixed martial arts gloves after nearly 20 years in the sport.

In 2019, Masvidal had his best year in MMA, rising to stardom and winning the BMF title against Nate Diaz at UFC 244. However, that was the last win of his career, and he subsequently fell to a four-fight losing streak. His final defeat was against Gilbert Burns by unanimous decision at UFC 287 on April 8. 

After his bout with "Durinho," Masvidal bid farewell to the UFC fans by announcing his MMA. In an interview with ESPN's Marc Raimondi shortly after making the decision, Masvidal was asked if he would compete again, and "Gamebred" shared that he decided to retire after noticing his reflexes were getting slower. 

However, now it seems Masvidal is interested in competing again ‚Äî but inside a boxing ring. 

Jorge Masvidal Shows Interest In Boxing, But Needs UFC Permission

Masvidal recently sat down for an interview on YouTuber-turned-boxer Jake Paul's show. He was asked whether he would compete in boxing, and whole Masvidal admitted interest in the venture, he noted one sizable hurdle. 

"Definitely, I would box. That is something that I wanted to do, especially since I started progressing more in my skillset and I have a pro boxing fight," Masvidal said. "It took place like 14, 15 years ago. Boxing was like, my first love, so I would definitely do a boxing match if the UFC permits me. They would have to give me permission. They'd have to be like, 'Yeah, go do your thing, you know.' If not, can't do no boxing match."

UFC fans may see Masvidal's problem as similar to former UFC welterweight and middleweight champion George St-Pierre.

The UFC blocked St-Pierre from competing against Oscar De La Hoya in 2021 because the Canadian was still under contract with the promotion. That was despite the fact that he was retired.

Masvidal is now seemingly facing the same problem, and won't be able to compete in boxing or MMA in a different company without permission from the UFC or a release from his contract with the organization. 

While Masvidal can't compete in pugilism, he has become a promoter for his own boxing company. He may not give him the same feeling as stepping into a ring, but he can still be involved in the sport and grow his brand. 

  • Read Also: Daniel Cormier Urges Jorge Masvidal To Stay Retired: "He Should Stay Away From The Game"

item.title: Report: Battle Between Top 10 Bantamweights Rob Font & Song Yadong In The Works For UFC 292
item.description: A clash between a pair of entertaining bantamweight contenders is reportedly in the works for UFC 292 on August 19. The promotion is set to head back to Boston, Massachusetts, in a few months' time for a pay-per-view event at the TD Garden. The card is set to feature championship fights at both ...
item.dc:creator: Harvey Leonard
item.content:encoded:
A clash between a pair of entertaining bantamweight contenders is reportedly in the works for UFC 292 on August 19.

The promotion is set to head back to Boston, Massachusetts, in a few months' time for a pay-per-view event at the TD Garden. The card is set to feature championship fights at both bantamweight and strawweight, with Aljamain Sterling defending his gold against Sean O'Malley in the main event.

And should things go to plan, "Funk Master" and "Sugar" may be joined by two other top 135lbers.

Per Eurosport Nederland's Marcel Dorff, a battle between the #7-ranked Rob Font and the contender one place below him on the divisional ladder, Song Yadong, is in the works for UFC 292.

Dorff noted that while the matchup is planned for the Boston-held PPV on August 19, it's yet to be officially signed,

Got told a bantamweight fight is in the works for #UFC292 in Boston on August 19th between #7 Rob Font and #8 Song Yadong. NOT signed at the moment. pic.twitter.com/hURe5KvtIE

— Marcel Dorff üá≥üá±üáÆüá© (@BigMarcel24) June 8, 2023

Font & Song In Pursuit Of Consecutive Victories

If everything goes according to plan, and Font and Song do collide this summer, both men will be looking to secure second straight victories.

Font (20-6) returned to the winner's circle this past April at UFC 287. After suffering back-to-back decision losses to Jos√© Aldo and Marlon Vera, the New England Cartel standout bounced back in style by knocking out Adrian Yanez in Miami.

He'll now pursue an entry into the bantamweight title picture by potentially stalling the rise of a contender 10 years his junior.

The 25-year-old Song (20-7-1, 1 NC) has long been touted as a future championship challenger at 135 pounds after debuting in the Octagon aged just 20. While he recorded impressive victories over Vera, Casey Kenney, and Marlon Moraes to climb the ladder, a headline loss to Cory Sandhagen paused his surge last September.

But having rebounded in the UFC Vegas 72 main event in April, where he stopped Ricky Sim√≥n via TKO early into the fifth round, the Chinese star could have the chance to resume his ascent against Font.

Should this expected addition come to fruition, the current fights expected to take place at UFC 292 on August 19 are as follows:

  • Aljamain Sterling (c) vs. Sean O'Malley (bantamweight championship main event)
  • Zhang Weili (c) vs. Amanda Lemos (strawweight championship co-main event)
  • Chris Weidman vs. Brad Tavares (middleweight)
  • Rob Font vs. Song Yadong (bantamweight)
  • Cody Garbrandt vs. Mario Bautista (bantamweight)
  • Gregory Rodrigues vs. Denis Tiuluilin (middleweight)
  • Gerald Meerschaert vs. Andre Petroski (middleweight)
  • Read Also: Chris Weidman Plans To 'Face His Fears' By Throwing Hard Leg Kick In Return From Horrific Injury At UFC 292

item.dc:creator: Harvey Leonard
item.content:encoded:
Just over a month ago, UFC bantamweight contender Irene Aldana was preparing for an Apex-held headliner against Raquel Pennington. Now, she's just days out from a date in the cage with one of, if not the, greatest female fighters of all time.

The switch came as a result of Julianna Pe√±a's forced withdrawal from the main event of the UFC 289 pay-per-view, set for this Saturday, June 10, at Rogers Arena in Vancouver, Canada.

After being drafted in to fill the void against Amanda Nunes, Aldana is pursuing what would no doubt go down as one of the biggest upsets in recent memory. Per BetOnline.ag, the reigning two-division champion currently sits as a -345 favorite to retain her 135-pound belt.

But when it comes to shocking the masses and upsetting the odds come fight night, Aldana isn't without useful insight.

Aldana Takes Inspiration From Champ Teammate Grasso

This past March, Alexa Grasso secured flyweight glory by submitting previously long-reigning queen Valentina Shevchenko at UFC 285. The Mexican trains alongside Aldana in Guadalajara.

Having witnessed her teammate join 125-pound kingpin Brandon Moreno and interim featherweight champ Yair Rodr√≠guez as her nation's third active titleholder, "Robles" has been inspired to add to Mexico's 2023 success inside the Octagon.

"(Grasso's title win was) very inspiring. It's a great motivation for me, seeing her accomplish that," Aldana said. "And not just accomplishing it, but the way she accomplished that. She shined that night. She won (against) one of the greatest of all time. Valentina Shevchenko is not an easy fight, we all know that. How she did that and how she managed all this, it was awesome.

"When she got to Guadalajara after her fight with Valentina, she went to my home and showed me her belt. The first thing she said was, 'You're next,'" Aldana recalled. "I was like, 'No, this is your time! Congratulations!' (She said), 'You're next.' It was great to see her like that and we have been looking back all this time. It has been a long journey and it is nice that we have shared this together, we have lived this together almost, at the same time."

Aldana will now look to channel her teammate's recent ability to overcome a sizable hurdle and repeat the feat herself at the expense of the consensus GOAT, Nunes.

If she does so this weekend on Canadian soil, it stands to reason that she'll be quickly home to Mexico to celebrate with the flyweight queen as the newly crowned bantamweight champ.

A face off with a view üòç#UFC289 Fight Week in Vancouver starting strong! pic.twitter.com/5OxVYxHSX2

— UFC (@ufc) June 7, 2023

item.title: Ariel Helwani Puts ABC President On Blast After On-Air Text Defending 'Broken' MMA Judging
item.description: Renowned combat sports reporter Ariel Helwani is one of many speaking out against the judging of mixed martial arts' fights following the latest controversy. In this past weekend's UFC Fight Night main event, flyweight contenders Kai Kara-France and Amir Albazi went the distance in pursuit of a ...
item.dc:creator: Harvey Leonard
item.content:encoded:
Renowned combat sports reporter Ariel Helwani is one of many speaking out against the judging of mixed martial arts' fights following the latest controversy.

In this past weekend's UFC Fight Night main event, flyweight contenders Kai Kara-France and Amir Albazi went the distance in pursuit of a place in the divisional title picture.

After a competitive 25 minutes, it was "The Prince" who emerged victorious via split decision, with judges Chris Lee and Sal D'Amato scoring the contest 48-47 in the Iraqi's favor.

To say the result has caused debate would be an understatement. With many who believe Kara-France deserved the nod acknowledging that D'Amato's verdict may be justifiable, the main point of criticism has been directed at the doorstep of Lee.

The often-discussed cageside scorer arrived at his final tally thanks to a widely debated decision to back Albazi's efforts in round four. On MMA Decisions, just 3.2 percent of 774 fan scorecards submitted as of this writing saw the frame the same way as Lee.

With that questionable scorecard ultimately handing Albazi a four-place rank rise, a potential title shot, and his win money, many prominent names in the community have called for change given what Kara-France was left missing out on ‚Äî although much of the criticism for the New Zealander's paycheck has also centered around the UFC's decision to employ a show/win remuneration structure.

One such vocal figure is Helwani, who recently laid into the mindset of the Association of Boxing Commissions (ABC).

Helwani Slams ABC Chief For Judging 'Secrecy'

During a recent episode of The MMA Hour, Helwani laid into ABC President Mike Mazzulli after receiving an on-air text about his remarks regarding the judging debate.

The ABC is a professional boxing and MMA organization that puts together contests and resides over record-keeping, and is governed by delegates of various forms of athletic commissions in the United States and Canada. Among its duties, the ABC approves the scoring criteria by which fights are judged.

Upon hearing Helwani's take on the recent controversy, the ABC's Mazzulli encouraged the reporter to attend the organization's scoring course ‚Äî which is free to attend for fighters and media members ‚Äî to better understand what the judges are observing.

While the likes of TSN's Aaron Bronsteter and the New York Post's Scott Fontana have credited the course for forming an improved knowledge of the criteria, Helwani insisted that Mazzulli's focus on non-judges improving their understanding deflects from the real issue.

1. We in MMA media should be pressing regulations to a allow them to let officials speak without fear of commission reprisal ‚Äî which is very real.

2. All MMA media members should attend the ABC classes to learn about officiating. It's way more than reading off a piece of paper. https://t.co/BaeBL3da7d

— Scott Fontana (@Scott_Fontana) June 7, 2023

For Helwani, that's a lack of transparency, explanation, and accountability.

"Just got a text message from Mike Mazzulli of the ABC," Helwani said. "(He wrote), 'I heard some of your podcast. I know you want to understand the scoring criteria and what the judges are looking at. Come to Vegas and attend the class. It is free to all fighters and press. Please state that on your next podcast.' I feel like 'please state that on your next podcast' is a very interesting way. I am stating it right now.

"Again, I will reiterate what I think both he and other people in these commission circles are missing, is the fact I know what it is... What I wanna know is what this guy is thinking on Saturday night when the rest of the world sees one thing and there's like five people on the planet that see another. That's what I want," Helwani continued. "I want to talk to the people. What they're trying to spin here is ‚Äî I don't wanna be a judge... I want to talk to the judges, I want to talk to the commission."

The Canadian journalist went on to call out Mazzulli and his organization for imposing a needless and damaging aura of "secrecy" around the judges, who at the moment aren't required to publicly explain their scorecards.

"Mazzulli likes to say, 'I need to protect the judges.' Why? That is their job. Again, I'm stating this as you want," Helwani exclaimed. "This secrecy around the judges like they work for the FBI, like, you signed up to this. And spare me the talk (that) they don't make enough, that's on you guys! You can pay them more if you want.

"Guess what? You're affecting people's pay. Kai Kara-France has $100,000 (less) in his bank account because of that fourth round," Helwani added. "So, 'Please state that on your podcast,' alright, I'll state that... Now please let me know why we can't talk to any of these judges and why you keep having Doug Crosby work your events. Can we state that on the podcast too? Come on, man."

Helwani went on to tie the discussion back to his and others' call for open scoring to be implemented.

He pointed to the ABC's refusal to engage in discourse with the fighters about the transparent method as another example of the athletes not getting a say in their careers.

"Why can't the fighters have a say? Why can't there be, at the ABC commission, a representative for the fighters who shows up and says, 'I want open scoring.' ... Why is it the same guys sitting around deciding the fate of these fighters and what's in their bank account? I'm so tired of this shit. I'm so tired of the old way of them doing it.

"Please tell me why your model is broken... When 98 percent of the fighters, and the audience, and the broadcasters, and everyone at home has no idea what you're looking at, that means it's broken... No one understands what the f*ck you're looking at... Do a better job of explaining it to the audience... All this is so wack."

The longtime combat sports reporter certainly isn't short on supporters when it comes to his desire for accountability, with a host of fighters and pundits also calling for judges to explain how they reach their verdicts.

That recently included UFC Middleweight Champion Israel Adesanya, who berated the scoring of his teammate Kara-France's setback against Albazi last Saturday.

Start interviewing the judges after fights.
Hold them accountable for their work.

— Israel Adesanya (@stylebender) June 4, 2023
  • Read Also: Jon Anik Critiques 'Really, Really Bad' Judging From Chris Lee, Says Kai Kara-France Was 'Robbed'
