item.title: Oleksandr Usyk's Co-Promoter Claims Saudi Arabia Will Send A Final Offer To Tyson Fury
item.description: The boxing community hopes to finally see the best heavyweights in the world compete on a big stage. talkSPORT's Simon Jordan revealed that Anthony Joshua, Deontay Wilder, Oleksandr Usyk, and Tyson Fury were all in discussions about competing in Saudi Arabia this December. The report shared that ...
item.dc:creator: Tyriece Simon
item.content:encoded:
The boxing community hopes to finally see the best heavyweights in the world compete on a big stage.

talkSPORT's Simon Jordan revealed that Anthony Joshua, Deontay Wilder, Oleksandr Usyk, and Tyson Fury were all in discussions about competing in Saudi Arabia this December. The report shared that Joshua would face Wilder, while Usyk would fight Fury in a potential unification bout. 

Currently, Usyk is the unified WBA (Super), WBO, IBF, and IBO Heavyweight Champion, and Fury holds the WBC's heavyweight gold. A unification bout can be difficult to put together, as other challengers are in line to compete for different titles in Usyk's position.

The WBA ordered Usyk to defend his title against Daniel Dubois, which is expected to occur on August 26. He also recently signed with Saudia Arabia boxing promotion Skill Challenge Entertainment However, the only wheels in motion for a heavyweight collision appears to be for Wilder vs. Joshua.

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Usyk. The Cat. Oleksandr (@usykaa)

Joshua's promoter Eddie Hearn has given updates to his fans regarding the dream matchup and has shared that they are optimistic about getting a deal done. Wilder's coach has also expressed that the fight will happen at the end of the year. 

In the meantime, "AJ" is expected to fight Dillian Whyte on August 12, which could help him prepare for a bout against Wilder. While it's not finalized, Wilder vs. Joshua seems to be moving in the right direction.

Unfortunately, Fury hasn't committed to an Usyk fight and has been calling out Joshua, UFC Heavyweight Champion Jon Jones, and new Professional Fighters League signee Francis Ngannou. 

Despite the callouts, boxing fans seemingly only want the Usyk unification fight. It now seems Saudia Arabia will make one final offer to make it happen.

Oleksandr Usyk's Co-Promoter Reveals Tyson Fury Will Be Getting Final Offer From Saudia Arabia

Usyk's co-promoter Alex Krassyuk spoke with iFL TV's Umar on June 6 about the progress of getting a fight agreement with Usyk and Fury. He shared that the Ukrainian has been willing to fight his British counterpart, even when the contract terms weren't in his favor. However, he suggested that Fury is unwilling to compete despite his remarks on social media.

Fury's promoter Frank Warren has insisted that Saudia Arabia is yet to send a written offer for "The Gypsy King" to fight Usyk. Now, Krassyuk has revealed that he expects Fury to get a final offer soon. 

"According to my knowledge, they will receive a formal written offer very soon, and it will be their decision or Tyson's decision whether to take it or leave it because we have done everything possible to make this fight happen, and now the ball is on Tyson's side," Krassyuk said. "It's an offer to take it or leave it. If you take it, then you have a big fight. The Biggest fight of your career.

"If you hesitate or if you try to trade out something or trying to swing around, it shows that you are not serious and you have to relinquish the belt and retire. Not for one month or for one week, as you use to retire shortly, recently, but probably forever," Krassyuk concluded.

It will be interesting to see how Fury will react to the potential ultimatum from Saudia Arabia. "The Gypsy King" seems to like being in control of negotiations, so boxing fans will have to wait and see if they can get the Brit to come to terms for a the long-awaited dream fight against Usyk.  

  • Read Also: Michael Bisping Says Tyson Fury vs. Jon Jones Would Do As Many PPV Buys As Floyd Mayweather vs. Conor McGregor

item.title: Charles Oliveira Reacts To Talk Of BMF Champion Leapfrogging Him For LW Title Shot
item.description: After failing to regain the 155-pound crown last October in Abu Dhabi, former UFC lightweight champion Charles Oliveira will shoot for a chance at redemption this weekend. In the co-main event of the UFC 289 pay-per-view, set for the Rogers Arena in Vancouver, Canada, on Saturday night, "Do Bronx" ...
item.dc:creator: Harvey Leonard
item.content:encoded:
After failing to regain the 155-pound crown last October in Abu Dhabi, former UFC lightweight champion Charles Oliveira will shoot for a chance at redemption this weekend.

In the co-main event of the UFC 289 pay-per-view, set for the Rogers Arena in Vancouver, Canada, on Saturday night, "Do Bronx" will share the Octagon with in-form contender Beneil Dariush.

The contest, which is widely seen as the card's 'people's main event', seemingly boasts incredibly high stakes, especially for Dariush. Following an eight-fight winning run, many believe the Iranian-born American has already done enough to earn a first title shot.

Nevertheless, he'll have one more challenge to pass before a likely showdown with reigning champion Islam Makhachev, and it'll be no easy task.

Despite falling short against Makhachev at UFC 280, Oliveira appears motivated to avenge the loss soon enough. In fact, despite the views of some, the Brazilian has insisted a rematch is on the cards for later this year.

Oliveira: Poirier vs. Gaethje Winner Won't Be Above Me

Ahead of Saturday's event in British Columbia, some have branded the co-main event a one-sided title eliminator. That includes Makhachev's American Kickboxing Academy coach Javier Mendez, who appears skeptical that a victory over Dariush will be enough for Oliveira to fight for the championship again.

With that, Mendez suggested that the UFC will likely turn to the upcoming BMF title fight between Dustin Poirier and Justin Gaethje in Salt Lake City on July 29 to select his pupil's next challenger.

But during his appearance at UFC 289 media day on Wednesday, Oliveira firmly dismissed the notion that the next BMF champ will be ahead of him in the pecking order should he stall Dariush's charge in Canada.

"Surely (it's me). Whoever wins this fight, this Saturday, is gonna go for the title," Oliveira said. "I'm next, I'm in line for it."

"Do Bronx" will no doubt look to boost his chances of a rematch with the Dagestani titleholder by putting on an emphatic performance come fight night this Saturday.

While the Brazilian was self-admittedly a shell of his usual self on Yas Island last October, he's promised a reinvigorated iteration of Charles Oliveira at UFC 289.

Charles Oliveira can do it ALL üí™@CharlesDoBronxs is back and ready for action at #UFC289 Saturday! pic.twitter.com/92nTVqRT8a

— UFC (@ufc) June 8, 2023
  • Read Also: Beneil Dariush: I'd Beat Charles Oliveira In '9 Out Of 10' Grappling Matches

item.title: Brendan Schaub: Fighters Should Boycott UFC 300 To Pressure Dana White, Others To Reform Judging
item.description: Former UFC fighter Brendan Schaub feels it's time for fighters to take action to enact change to MMA's judging system. Kai Kara-France lost to Amir Albazi by split decision at the UFC Fight Night event last weekend. Despite many believing that the New Zealander deserved the win, two of the ...
item.dc:creator: Curtis Calhoun
item.content:encoded:
Former UFC fighter Brendan Schaub feels it's time for fighters to take action to enact change to MMA's judging system.

Kai Kara-France lost to Amir Albazi by split decision at the UFC Fight Night event last weekend. Despite many believing that the New Zealander deserved the win, two of the judges' scorecards went in his Iraqi counterpart's favor.

Many of Kara-France's fighting colleagues have criticized the two judges, Sal D'Amato and Chris Lee, for scoring the fight for Albazi. UFC Middleweight Champion Israel Adesanya went as far as to accuse some judges of ruining the livelihoods of some athletes.

Schaub, who picked up wins over Mirko Cro Cop and Gabriel Gonzaga during his UFC career, feels it's up to fighters to bring the issue of controversial judging to the spotlight.

Brendan Schaub: Fighters Should Take Action Against Questionable Judging

During a recent episode of The Schaub Show, Schaub pitched an interesting way for judging to potentially change in MMA.

"There has to be something we can do here," Schaub said. "You can do what the SAG writers and just protest...what you do is rally the troops, do it before the big event, UFC 300, the week of...'Guess what? Unless there's a change, we aren't fighting. '... If the fighters decided to put their foot in the ground, two days and things would change."

As of this writing, the UFC doesn't have an athlete-led union, although that could change amidst the ongoing fighter pay debate and other hot topics in the sport.

Open scoring is another solution that has been presented by some to combat head-scratching scorecards. Judges currently aren't required to reveal their perspective as to why they score specific fights the way they do.

UFC 300 will take place next year and will likely be a massive event in the promotion's history. But, Schaub sees it as also being an opportunity for fighters to demand certain changes sport-wide.

item.title: Nate Landwehr Bemoans Dan Ige's 'Wack' Trash Talk, Warns That He'll Be Fighting A 'F**king Monster'
item.description: UFC featherweight Nate Landwehr isn't amused by some of Dan Ige's recent remarks. Landwehr and Ige, the #13-ranked contender at 145 pounds, are set to do battle on the UFC 289 main card. The pay-per-view event will take place at the Rogers Arena in Vancouver, Canada, this Saturday. Ahead of the ...
item.dc:creator: Harvey Leonard
item.content:encoded:
UFC featherweight Nate Landwehr isn't amused by some of Dan Ige's recent remarks.

Landwehr and Ige, the #13-ranked contender at 145 pounds, are set to do battle on the UFC 289 main card. The pay-per-view event will take place at the Rogers Arena in Vancouver, Canada, this Saturday.

Ahead of the contest, many have expressed high expectations. Given both men's entertaining history and penchant for striking firefights, some are predicting that the pair will leave British Columbia with Fight of the Night honors.

Should that be the case, "50K" is expecting to return home with both another bonus check and a victory added to his record. In the buildup, Ige has claimed he can "make it look easy" against Landwehr.

The top 15 featherweight has even sought to use his opponent's nickname against him, insisting that he will control and derail "The Train" come fight night on June 10.

Evidently, Ige has a tough crowd when it comes to Landwehr...

Landwehr Grades Ige's Trash Talk: 'That's The Oldest One'

During his appearance at UFC 289 media day on Wednesday, Landwehr reacted to Ige's pre-fight remarks, branding his play on words unoriginal and "wack."

"The Train" went on to note that while Ige enters the event as a favorite who will be defending his place on the ladder from below, he'll be locked in the cage with a "monster" in Vancouver.

"You know, when I see stuff like that (Ige's trash talk), I'm like, man, at least have an original idea. I've never heard that one. I've never head, 'I wanna derail the train,'" Landwehr said sarcastically. "That's the oldest one. I've heard that probably like ‚Äî come up with something! It's kind of like, that's wack. 

"I get it. You can't think of nothing else cool to say. You might as well go to that," Landwehr continued. "Every day when I was going to sleep for this fight camp, I knew I was fighting one of the best in the world. But every day, he goes to sleep knowing he's fighting a f**king monster."

To earn a shot at the featherweight rankings, Landwehr has won three straight since a TKO loss to Julian Erosa back in 2021.

After submitting ƒΩudov√≠t Klein and outpointing David Onama in a memorable Fight of the Night scrap at UFC San Diego, "The Train" made it a hat-trick of bonuses this past March at UFC San Antonio, where he forced Austin Lingo to tap.

The former M-1 Global champion will now look to continue that run of form in what will no doubt mark the stiffest test of his Octagon career to date.

  • Read Also: 'Big' John McCarthy Blasts Lack Of 'Pay-Per-View Quality' Fights At UFC 289
